p: A. indica, also known as ‘neem tree‘, is considered by many people living in Africa as a miraculous plant for a wide range of uses in ethnopharmacology such as anthelmintic, antimalarial, anti-inflammatory purposes and for healing skin diseases. Most of these properties were then confirmed by scientific reports [ 16, 17, 18]. All parts of the plant can be used for medicinal purposes, including the seed oil extracted by mechanical pressure [ 19, 20]. Notably, the ethanolic extract obtained from neem stem bark exhibited activity against T. b. brucei [ 21], whereas the leaf essential oil has been barely investigated to date.
